data.name: Cream Ale
data.description: Made especially for those looking for a light beer.  Very similar to your standard American lager but brewed with ale yeast.   Medium-light bodied and smooth, golden in color and low in bitterness.  This beer has a clean, sweet malt profile with a hint of buttered toast in the aroma & flavor.

style.name: American-Style Cream Ale or Lager
style.description: Mild, pale, light-bodied ale, made using a warm fermentation (top or bottom) and cold lagering. Hop bitterness and flavor range from very low to low. Hop aroma is often absent. Sometimes referred to as cream ales, these beers are crisp and refreshing. Pale malt character predominates. Caramelized malt character should be absent. A fruity or estery aroma may be perceived. Diacetyl and chill haze should not be perceived. Sulfur character and/or sweet corn-like dimethylsulfide (DMS) should be extremely low or absent from this style of beer.

breweries.name: Fenton Winery & Brewery
breweries.description: The Fenton Winery & Brewery is located on a beautiful, 5 acre property in Fenton Township. At over 1 acre, the beer garden is one (if not the) largest in the state. The taproom is located right alongside the brewery and is around the corner from the winery - all in full view of patrons. FWB specializes in crafting balanced wines and beers that maximize flavor and originality. Food is available - from tasty specialty meat & cheese plates, to delicious sandwiches and specialty pizzas. Definitely worth a stop (or three). Cheers!

breweries.name: Taps Fish House & Brewery
breweries.description:
TAPS Fish House & Brewery was founded in 1999. Many of our beers reflect the classic brewing traditions of Europe, including England, Germany, and Belgium, while others are indicative of the creativity and innovation that are the hallmarks of the American Craft Beer scene.

TAPS’ repertoire of ales and lagers is highly varied and reflects a nod to tradition with a focus on perfection and innovation. The brewing team produces approximately 3000 kegs, or 46,500 gallons of beer annually. Our brewers supply TAPS in Brea, Corona and Irvine, as well as our sister restaurants, The Catch in Anaheim and Lillie’s Q in Brea Downtown. TAPS also distributes fine beers to restaurants and pubs throughout Southern California. We have received national and international acclaim for barrel-aging programs, which produce cult classics such as Remy’s Pappy.

We source the finest ingredients from around the world and utilize the best brewing procedures to create truly great beer: “World Class in Every Glass.” The hops and barley are meticulously sourced in order to emulate the fine beers and brewing regions of the world.  We utilize proprietary strains of yeast, reverse osmosis filtration, and tailor our water chemistry and processes every time beer is made.

TAPS’ passion for perfection has been recognized on the regional, state, national and international levels—to date we have received over 87 medals for our fine beers. TAPS barrel-aged products have also garnered national and international acclaim and are treasured by collectors worldwide

data.name: Cream Ale
data.description:
Most of America's beer styles have been imported from Europe.  However, Cream Ale is one of the distinctly American styles and it's seeing a resurgence in craft brewing.  

Our Cream Ale began it's life as a summer seasonal, but quickly turned into one of the staples of our lineup. Our Cream Ale is a crisp, clean, easy-drinking light hybrid beer.  The hops provide a subtle spicy/sweet aroma while the yeast produces a nice crisp finish due to the cooler fermentation temperature.  

It's the perfect beer to compliment a great round of disc golf.

breweries.name: Blind Squirrel
breweries.description: The Vance Toe River Lodge was originally built in 1919 as the T. B. Vance General Store. After trading hands through the years and seeing its fair share of abuse it was renovated by the Young family and continues to evolve.  With that evolution came the expansion of our  “Lodge Family”.  When Aaron Maas moved to Plumtree, NC in 2009 as an avid home brewer, the dream to open a brewery slowly moved towards reality.  After 3 painstaking years, the brewery finally opened in July of 2012.  We are excited to be able to live in such a wonderful place and still have the ability to follow our passions.  Come out to Plumtree so we can prove to you that we’re nuts about beer!!

breweries.name: Full Sail Brewing Company
breweries.description: Perched on a bluff in Hood River, Oregon, overlooking the mighty Columbia River’s epic wind and kite surfing and the snow-capped volcanic peaks of Mt. Hood, Full Sail is a true craft-brewing pioneer. Since 1987, Full Sail has been pouring pure Mt. Hood water, local ingredients and responsible processes into each and every pint. Full Sail’s brews and sustainable practices have garnered more than 300 national and international awards, including 150 gold medals and Beverage World‘s “Craft Brewer of the Year” distinction. From Full Sail Amber and IPA to Session Lager and bourbon barrel-aged beers, Full Sail consistently strives to brew complex, balanced and ridiculously tasty beers.

breweries.name: Lily's Seafood Grill & Brewery
breweries.description:
Lily's Seafood has been delivering exquisite seafood in a relaxed and comfortable environment since 1999. The Morton brothers opened the restaurant with a passion at heart to bring unique, quality food, perfectly crafted micro-brews and a cozy, relaxed, family friendly atmosphere to downtown Royal Oak . That passion is evident in every dish and pint they serve.

It is in the spirit of the Morton brother's grandmother Lily A. Strange, a Scottish immigrant who brought to this country her love of family, sense of style, and appreciation of fine food that Lily's was created. The Morton brothers have recreated the feeling of their grandparent's home inside the walls of Lily's, tucked into Royal Oak 's vibrant downtown. Lily's is a place to gather and to share not only fine food and drink, but laughter, love, conversation, and fond memories.

breweries.name: Wicked Beaver Brewing Company
breweries.description:
Wicked Beaver is a West Texas Craft Brewery, formed in Spring of 2009. We are a hands-on Brewery, with no automation to speak of, this keeps us in touch with every batch of beer we brew.

On an old dirt road, far from the beaten path, deep in the midst of no-where lives a Wicked Beaver. Why is he Wicked, you may ask? He is Wicked from the ways of the world, so many demands, too many deadlines, minor appreciation, and never enough time. So with little more than the stick in his hand and the Hops in his hanker chief, he journeyed West. Upon arriving in the West he hopped from the tailgate, choked on the dust, and kicked a tumble weed rolling his direction. This is the West, the place full of opportunity “he asked himself” and sighed but after a few Wicked Cold months, the landscape began to change, grass became lush green, trees bloomed and the flowers opened. The Wicked Beaver found the warm days, and cool nights were perfect to pursue his passion.

The Wicked Beaver and his brewing partners have been Brewing Craft Specialty Beer’s in secret for years, perfecting the fragrant aroma by blending only best hops and hand selecting the Malted Barley for the most unique varieties of flavors and textures. The Wicked Beaver is ready to share his unique creations with you!

If Spokane were a liquid it would most certainly be our beer. Born & Raised in Washington’s Inland Empire, we’re an internationally award-winning brewery, crafting Spokane-Style beers with No Boundaries: innovative beers made in Spokane, by Spokane residents, using ingredients sourced from within 300 miles of Spokane. We create beers that push ourselves & No-Li drinkers beyond the boundaries… taking a leap beyond the typical beer-drinking experience, and into a memorable adventure. No Boundaries, No-Li!

The pub features Inland Northwest-style pub food, with an emphasis on "keeping it local." Most of the dishes are created from scratch, and use as many locally sourced ingredients as possible. 

For more information about our beers, brewery & the pub, visit www.nolibrewhouse.com.

data.name: Crooked Lake Cream Ale
data.description: Accurate to style, historically this type of ale was brewed to compete with the fast growth of the American Lager style.  The addition of corn as an adjunct dates back to early America, when malted barley was hard to come by.  This recipe uses a flaked maize and pale malt blend with a light Cluster hop for bitterness to create an easy drinking and thirst quenching lawnmower beer. Note: this style would easily double as a great dock beer!

data.name: Croydon Cream Ale
data.description: Often called your typical American lawnmower beer, cream ales are not unlike their American light lager cousin. Brewed with two and six row continental barley, flaked maize, a touch of Munich malt, and of course, sugar, Croydon Cream Ale is light, refreshing, and easy to drink. breweries.name: Jack Pine Brewery
breweries.description:
Most homebrewers, at some point, begin to dream of starting their own brewery.  I had always liked my beer, but I realized that there tends to be a brewer’s bias towards their own beer.  A great deal of time and effort goes into making a batch of beer, so the brewer is bound to speak highly of their own goods.  It turns out, I’m my own worst critic.  I’m constantly searching for ways to improve the beer.  Whenever I shared brews with others, they always liked it as well, but who doesn’t like free beer?  For me, the seed was planted quite a few years ago when I started winning homebrewing awards statewide.  It was then I began to realize that I was making more than just pretty good homebrew.  I was making some damn good beer!  I began volunteering to judge at homebrew competitions and making an effort to get out and sample more of the beers not available in northern Minnesota.  I quickly realized that there was much more to explore in the world of beer than I realized.  I studied and tasted everything I could find regarding brewing science and beer styles.  In the midst of all of the studying and research, I took the Beer Judge Certification Program test and obtained a National rank in the BJCP.  I now had some credentials to back up my knowledge of good beer and brewing.  It was clear that this was starting to become more than just a hobby, so I began to put a bit more time and effort into the dream of starting a brewery.

So, after all this research and planning, what’s the plan?  Start small.

Jack Pine Brewery is starting very small.  Nanobrewery small.  Brewing forty gallons at a time small.  Did I mention the brewer is small?

This little brewery serves as a pilot system for the eventual build-out of a full scale production brewery.  It provides the opportunity to test the waters before sinking a boatload of cash into a warehouse full of stainless equipment.  Best of all, it gives YOU a chance to TRY THE BEER!  I’ve been my own worst critic for the past 12 years of homebrewing.  Now it’s your turn.  With your help, we can build a brewery to provide our friends and neighbors with delicious locally-brewed beer.

So, stop in and give it a try!

breweries.name: Foxhole Brewhouse
breweries.description: After being introduced to a "dark" beer at our local bowling alley we were hooked. Our love of craft beer took off and soon that turned into homebreweing. Now that's were the fun began! Two plus years of obsessive homebrewing (which is the only way Ryan works when he has a idea in his head) to a drive to learn about professional brewing brings us to the point...Foxhole Brewhouse. Why Foxhole? Well, our last name means Fox in German and Liv in all her "slyness" thought our home was our foxhole. We got a few good laughs, threw a few homebrew parties and it stuck. There hasn't been a brewery in Willmar since 1899 and we think it's time to bring it back with fresh, local, handcrafted beer! Not the fizzy yellow stuff massed produced and stripped of all the wonderful flavors that are meant to be in there. I mean small batch, flavorful and aromatic beer. Variety too, there are so many amazing varieties of beer that can be crafted we get excited thinking about brewing them for everyone to taste. Damn I'm thirsty...time to get brewing...see you soon!

breweries.name: Fullsteam Brewery
breweries.description:
Fullsteam is a Durham, North Carolina brewery inspired by the agricultural and culinary traditions of the South.

Our mission is to craft a distinctly Southern beer style using local farmed goods, heirloom grains, and Southern botanicals. Like what, you wonder? We're making beer with sweet potatoes, corn grits, summer basil, and malted barley house-smoked over hickory. Other successful "plow to pint" experiments to-date include beer brewed with scuppernong grapes, persimmon, paw paw, rhubarb and more. 

Ultimately, our vision is to craft a year-round, sustainable, scalable, and distinctly Southern beer brewed 100% with local ingredients. That's the quest. We're a long ways from realizing this vision, but we hope you enjoy the adventure as much as we expect to. Interested? Read more about Southern-style beer.

breweries.name: Short's Brewing Company
breweries.description:
In April of 2004 we opened the doors to Short’s Brewing Company in the quaint Village of Bellaire.  Beer was the mission, and liberation was the movement.  With a lot of elbow grease, blind ambition and a little luck, the quest to create a community pub in Northwest Lower Michigan began to take shape.  The philosophy was to bring an appreciation of craft beer to the north with product education and creativity.  The process of appreciation through education we call beer liberation.

Today Short’s Brewing Company continues the effort to educate and liberate consumers.  We take pride in our hands on, mom and pop approach and the energy we put into the quality of our beer, food, staff, customers and facilities. We believe in the power of the smallness.   We intend on remaining a smaller, state wide beer distributor and focusing our energies close to home (the SBC Michigan stimulus package).  Our goal is to get to a comfortable production volume, enjoy what we do and love life in Northern Michigan.

breweries.name: Horny Goat Brewing Company
breweries.description: We’re often questioned about the origin of our name. Our story has it that “Spanish Fly Brewing” sounded too clumsy. Another says it was a bet at a card game. A third we’ve been advised by our lawyers not to discuss. While each rendition may have some truth to it, what it really boils down to is quite simple: Beer is fun. Brewing is fun. Drinking beer with your buddies is fun. So, why not a name that’s fun? After all, we’re in the business of helping people enjoy life. And we take our business very seriously. Our beers are craft-brewed for Old World taste and new world refreshment. Savored, slammed or sipped,these beers are also brewed to be sold and we plan on selling a lot of them. Aggressive marketing campaigns are in place to make sure Horny Goat Beers are on the radar of beer purchasers in select markets. Radio commercials, point-of-sale, guerilla tactics, swag, social media, you name it ‘cause we plan on growing, and growing large quickly. Kind of like a horny goat. So prepare yourself, the world is about to become a much hornier place.

data.name: Fallen Apple
data.description: My goal in building the recipe for Fallen Apple was to create a seasonal specialty that was in and of itself a celebration. I start with fresh-pressed cider from early harvest apples we get from Kickapoo Orchards in Gays Mills. Fermentation leaves the cider tart and champagne-like. I then brew a cream ale designed to put some sweetness and body back into the beer, which rounds out the sour apple notes. This combination of ethereal apple flavor grounded in an “everyman’s” beer makes for a festive and potent brew.

breweries.name: Furthermore Beer
breweries.description:
Furthermore bought a building way back in 2005 with the hopes of shoe-stringing together an undersized, Frankenstein-style brewery. The reason for so lofty a goal was of course to cheaply serve the more important purpose of the business--getting beer to the beer drinker, putting bottles on the shelf. However, even “cheap” was expensive to us. Pinching pennies and moving cautiously wasn’t helping us reach our self imposed deadline of Summer of 2006. Then we met the good folks at Sand Creek Brewing Co (Black River Falls, WI) who agreed to bring us on as customers, allowing us to use their facility to get the beer brewed. We were thus able to skip the hard lessons of construction pitfalls and went straight to filling stainless steel tanks with beer. 

The scrape-together building and used equipment model was then blacked out from the “Phase 1” section of the business plan. Aran went on the road to be hands on at Sand Creek; Chris went on the road to sell beer. We have since acquired another property in Spring Green (known affectionately as the Shitty Barn), and we have often been heard threatening to build a brewery on this site, sometimes quite convincingly. But “if it ain’t broke, don’t fix it” seems to be the winning adage. So until we break it, we won’t likely fix our present model. 

So that is the back story--the mental seasoning for your next sip of Furthermore Beer. Fair warning to the newcomer: those who like our beers always seem to find at least one to stick in the “hate” column—ant that’s always one that someone else places in the “love” column with a glittery heart sticker next to it. So remember, if you have distaste for one of our beers, it could our failings, or it could be your poor upbringing and resulting prejudices--so hate with an open mind.

breweries.name: Ploughshare Brewing Co.
breweries.description: The brewery identity authentically reflects Nebraska history… homestead ideals of hard work, self-sufficiency, simple pleasures and wholesome refreshment. Ploughshare offers a rotation of our hand-crafted beer on 12 taps. We have four year-round brews and many adventurous seasonals released throughout the year.  Every other week, we showcase a cask of naturally-conditioned Ploughshare beer, usually with an unusual spicing or hop addition.  Every once in a while we release a hand-bottled super-premium brew from our conditioning tanks or barrel program. We are currently distributed in Eastern Nebraska.

data.name: Farmer Ted's
data.description: This beer is an indigenous American beer style created as an answer to post-prohibition German lagers.  We pay tribute to the beers made on early, rustic systems by using natural ingredients like corn and barley to create a smooth and full-bodied, straw-colored ale.  Reward yourself with a Farmer Ted’s after a long day plowing the fields, or just after mowing the lawn!

data.name: Flagship

This gold-medal winning cream ale is the perfect session beer for any occasion. Available on draft and in 12-ounce cans.

breweries.name: Garage Brewing Co.
breweries.description:
We are a state-of-the art 10 BBL brewery and fast casual restaurant in an old automotive center at the end of Old Town Front Street in Temecula. 
 
The brewery equipment was manufacured in North America by a company that has built over 350 breweries and has over 25 years of experience in the craft brewing industry. This customized equipment allows us to make truly exceptional beer with a high level of consistency. 

Equipment doesn’t begin and end in the brew house. An often-overlooked main ingredient in beer is the water. Often brewers will believe that their local water source adds to their individuality of their product, or what wine makers call terroir. While this may be true to a large extent it overlooks the importance of a beer style’s original water source when trying to replicate a specific style.  Without our Reverse Osmosis water filtration system we feel that producing a beer originating from a region with “soft” water just wouldn’t bring that beer justice, being that our own regional water is extremely hard.  Reverse Osmosis gives us flexibility and allows us to properly pay respect and more accurately replicate brewing traditions from all over the world.
 
Our brewing system also wouldn’t be complete without putting thought into the storage of our beer. Many fantastic beers leave breweries and then suffer the consequences of entering the distribution chain that wasn’t at all designed to deal with craft beer. At Garage Brewing Co, we choose our guest beer that has been handled with the utmost care, and we store our own beer just steps from where it was brewed and fermented. Our 10 BBL serving vessels ensure beer delivery in its freshest form and our draft/tap system is highly engineered to ensure that we can pour our guests a proper pint.

Many hours of thought and years of experience have been drawn from to ensure that Garage Brewing Co not only produces and serves and exceptional beer to its guests but does so in a way that respects the old world traditions.
